title: How to Paint a Barn

steps.headline: Evaluate the surface of your barn before painting.
steps.description: Leaks in the roof, cracks in the walls and other structural problems should be corrected prior to barn painting to ensure that the job lasts. A power washer works well, though you may need to scrub some areas by hand.

steps.headline: Wash the surface of your barn to remove dirt, grime and loose paint chips.
Scrape all loose paint chips off the surface of the barn.
steps.description: Use chemical paint remover for stubborn areas.

steps.headline: Select an exterior latex paint that is 100 percent acrylic.
Allow the surface of your barn to dry before beginning to paint.
steps.description: Make sure rain is not in the forecast. Expect to use a gallon of paint for every 300 to 400 square feet (91.44 to 121.92 meters).

steps.headline: Look at your barn once you finish the first coat of paint to determine if it needs a second.
steps.description: If it does Repeat the last steps.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat to your barn, if needed.
Paint windows, doors, hardware and trim with an enamel paint.
